title: The Best And Worst Chest Exercises (Ranked By Science)

S-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) by providing a nice deep stretch on the pecs and high tension throughout the entire range of motion. Meets criterion 2 (feels good) because the locked-in nature of the machine helps increase the mind-muscle connection with the pecs and gives a massive pump. Meets criterion 3 (simple progression) as machines are very easy to overload by adding weight or reps from week to week, and they offer the advantage of being safer to push to failure than free weights.
S-Tier.limitations: Effectiveness depends on finding a good quality machine that meets the criteria.
S-Tier.additional_notes: This exercise is crowned as the 'best of the best' (S-tier Plus) for chest growth.

S-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) by providing a big stretch on the pecs with nice, smooth, and even tension throughout the range of motion, similar to cable crossovers. Meets criterion 2 (feels good) because sitting down eliminates the balancing component and increases the stability of the exercise, ensuring that all tension from the cables is applied directly to the pecs. Meets criterion 3 (simple progression) as it's a cable exercise where reps and technique can be focused on for overload.
S-Tier.alternative_options: Compared to Cable Crossovers, the seated position removes the balancing component and increases stability.
S-Tier.additional_notes: This is the speaker's favorite chest isolation movement at the moment.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Bring the bar all the way down to your chest.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) as it offers high tension on the pecs when the bar is brought all the way down. Meets criterion 3 (simple progression) as it's very easy to overload by adding weight over time. Slightly fails criterion 1 (big stretch) compared to dumbbells because the barbell comes up solid against the rib cage, preventing the pec from getting as deep of a stretch. Slightly fails criterion 2 (feels good) as many people complain that it makes their shoulders feel cranky (often suspected to be due to ego lifting), and not everyone gets as much pec activation.
A-Tier.limitations: Barbell limits the depth of pec stretch compared to dumbbells. Can cause shoulder crankiness for some individuals. Not everyone achieves optimal pec activation.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Compared to dumbbell presses, the barbell limits the depth of the pec stretch.
A-Tier.additional_notes: The speaker credits most of his own pec development to this exercise.

A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) and criterion 3 (simple progression) with the same upsides as the flat bench press. Meets criterion 2 (feels good) for most individuals. It slightly emphasizes the upper pecs.
A-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Upper pecs (slightly emphasized), also causes the same lower and mid pec growth as the flat bench.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Compared to the flat bench press, it slightly emphasizes the upper pecs.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: A recent study found that the incline bench press caused the same lower and mid pec growth as the flat bench did, plus better upper pec growth.

A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) as dumbbells allow for a deeper stretch on the pecs than a barbell because they can move freely past the rib cage. Meets criterion 2 (feels good) as they feel great, provide a great chest pump, and are less likely to cause shoulder issues for beginners and intermediate lifters. Meets criterion 3 (simple progression) for beginner and intermediate lifters by adding reps or increasing dumbbell weight. Slightly fails criterion 3 for advanced lifters because they may max out the dumbbell rack (e.g., 100lb) and large dumbbells can become awkward to handle.
A-Tier.limitations: Advanced lifters may max out the available dumbbell weight (e.g., 100lb). Large dumbbells can become bulky and awkward to handle for stronger lifters.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Offers a deeper stretch on the pecs compared to the barbell press.

A-Tier.tier_reasons: Same basic movement with the same upsides and downsides as the flat dumbbell press. Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension), criterion 2 (feels good), and criterion 3 (simple progression) for most. It has slightly more emphasis on the upper pecs.
A-Tier.limitations: Advanced lifters may max out the available dumbbell weight (e.g., 100lb). Large dumbbells can become bulky and awkward to handle for stronger lifters.

A-Tier.setup_notes: Can be performed as assisted dips (reduce assistance weight over time), bodyweight dips (add reps, slow down the negative), or weighted dips (use a weight belt to add external load).
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) as it provides a massive stretch on the pecs, possibly the best compound exercise for getting into a deep pec stretch, and offers high tension. Meets criterion 3 (simple progression) with many ways to apply progressive overload. Slightly fails criterion 2 (feels good) as some people find their shoulders get cranky if they do them too much, and the speaker personally doesn't find them to have the smoothest feel.
A-Tier.limitations: Can cause shoulder crankiness for some individuals. May not have the smoothest feel for everyone.

A-Tier.execution_notes: To make the exercise more challenging, pause for 2 to 3 seconds in the bottom position.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) as they fix the problem of not getting a deep stretch on the pecs (unlike standard push-ups). Meets criterion 3 (simple progression) as the exercise can be made more challenging by pausing at the bottom.
A-Tier.limitations: Still a bit tricky to overload effectively.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Fixes the limited stretch problem of standard bodyweight push-ups.
A-Tier.additional_notes: If you're going to do push-ups, this is how you should do them.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Perform the same basic movement as a barbell guillotine press, but with dumbbells. This involves flaring elbows out and lowering the dumbbells to the neck area.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) as it stretches the pecs better than any of the other barbell presses discussed. Meets criterion 2 (feels good/safe) because modifying the exercise to use dumbbells makes it much safer than the barbell version. Meets criterion 3 (simple progression) as it's a press that can be progressively overloaded.
A-Tier.limitations: May cause shoulder pain for some individuals, especially those with pre-existing shoulder issues; start light and build up tolerance.
A-Tier.alternative_options: This is a much safer modification of the barbell Guillotine Press.
A-Tier.additional_notes: The majority of lifters can flare their elbows without issue.

A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) and criterion 3 (simple progression) with all the same upsides as the standard bench press. Meets criterion 2 (feels good/safe) as the locked-in nature allows for more confidence in pushing closer to failure.
A-Tier.alternative_options: A great alternative to the standard bench press.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: Studies consistently show that the Smith machine is effective at building muscle across a variety of different exercises.

A-Tier.tier_reasons: Same basic movement as the Smith machine press with the same upsides. Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension), criterion 2 (feels good), and criterion 3 (simple progression). It has a little more upper pec emphasis.

A-Tier.execution_notes: To correct for instability, bend forward and fly downward.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) by providing a big stretch on the pecs with nice, smooth, and even tension throughout the range of motion. Meets criterion 2 (feels good) as they feel good and usually give a solid chest pump. Slightly fails criterion 3 (simple progression) as they are not as conducive to progressive overload as pressing movements (can't go as heavy), though reps and technique can still be focused on. Slightly fails criterion 2 (feels good/stable) as performing them standing may cause the cable to pull the body back, making it less stable.
A-Tier.limitations: Not as conducive to heavy progressive overload as pressing movements. Standing position can lead to instability as the cable pulls the body back.

A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) by allowing a big stretch on the pecs with high tension. Meets criterion 2 (feels good/stable) as being seated provides stability. Slightly fails criterion 2 (feels good) as it doesn't feel quite as good as cables, locking the user into a very specific movement path which may not allow for finding the perfect line of pull for individual pecs.
A-Tier.limitations: Locks the user into a very specific movement path, which may not suit everyone's individual biomechanics for optimal pec activation.
A-Tier.alternative_options: Compared to cable flies, the machine locks you into a specific movement path, whereas cables allow for more free shoulder movement.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Can be performed as length-biased partials by cutting out the top half of the movement where there is no tension.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) as recent evidence highlights the importance of the stretch for muscle growth, making it a viable option despite having zero tension at the top of the range of motion. Slightly fails criterion 2 (feels good) as they are not as smooth as cable flies.
A-Tier.limitations: Zero tension at the top of the range of motion when the pecs are most contracted. Not as smooth as cable flies.
A-Tier.scientific_insights: Recent evidence has shown that the contraction is most likely not as important as the stretch is for muscle growth.

A-Tier.execution_notes: Press the cable across your midline.
A-Tier.tier_reasons: Meets criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) by getting the pec fully contracted, as it's a rare exercise where the cable is pressed across the midline. Meets criterion 2 (feels good) once the movement is mastered. Meets criterion 3 (simple progression) as it's a cable exercise that can be progressively overloaded.
A-Tier.limitations: The movement can be a bit awkward at first.
A-Tier.additional_notes: The speaker loves this exercise and includes it periodically for short-length biased work until more evidence is available.

B-Tier.tier_reasons: Slightly fails criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) due to having slightly less range of motion than both the flat and incline presses. Fails criterion 2 (feels good/optimal for most) because, in the speaker's experience, more people struggle with upper pec growth than mid to lower pecs, so biasing towards the mid and lower pecs is not ideal for the majority. Biomechanics suggests it targets mid and lower pecs more.
B-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Mid and lower pecs (biomechanically targeted more).
B-Tier.limitations: Slightly less range of motion than flat and incline bench presses. May not be optimal for most individuals who need more upper pec emphasis.
B-Tier.alternative_options: Compared to flat and incline bench presses, it has slightly less range of motion.
B-Tier.scientific_insights: No long-term research comparing pec growth like the incline and flat bench presses.
B-Tier.additional_notes: The speaker's least favorite among the three angle options for bench press.

B-Tier.setup_notes: You'll probably need someone to hand you the dumbbells for setup.
B-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 2 (feels good/convenient) as it's awkward to set up, often requiring assistance to hand off the dumbbells. Fails criterion 2 (feels good/optimal for most) because lower pecs rarely need any extra emphasis for most individuals.
B-Tier.limitations: Awkward to set up, often requiring assistance.

B-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) because almost all of the extra tension from the band is added to the top half of the push-up, rather than the bottom half, meaning tension is still not maximized while the pecs are stretched.
B-Tier.limitations: Tension is not maximized when the pecs are stretched.

C-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) because you come up solid against the floor before your pecs are fully stretched. Fails criterion 3 (simple progression) because once you get decently strong, you'll need to do at least 30+ reps to get close enough to failure for maximal muscle growth, which is not ideal. Overloading by having a partner add weight to your back feels unstable.
C-Tier.limitations: Requires high reps (30+) to maximize muscle growth for stronger individuals. Limited pec stretch due to hitting the floor. Difficult to overload effectively with added weight (unstable).
C-Tier.additional_notes: A decent beginner exercise. Can be used as an end-of-workout finisher.

C-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) because the limited range of motion prevents the pecs from ever getting fully stretched, making it a less than ideal candidate for chest hypertrophy.
C-Tier.limitations: Limited range of motion, preventing full pec stretch.
C-Tier.additional_notes: Mainly used for developing maximum bench press strength. Great for smashing the triceps and improving lockout strength. The speaker loves it for strength but rates it 'just okay' for pec growth.

D-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 2 (feels good) for pecs because the speaker and nearly every client he has worked with do not feel their pecs when performing this movement. Despite some theoretical merit and activation data, it's considered a much better lat exercise than a pec exercise.
D-Tier.limitations: Poor mind-muscle connection for the pecs for many individuals.
D-Tier.scientific_insights: Biomechanics suggests that the pecs do help perform this movement alongside the lats and triceps. Activation data shows that the pecs do activate on pullovers.

D-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) as they are not great for maximizing tension on the negative or in the stretch phase of the movement.
D-Tier.limitations: Not effective for maximizing tension on the negative or in the stretch.
D-Tier.scientific_insights: While there is some research supporting more explosive training, for bodybuilding goals, it's preferable to use an explosive tempo on a weight-loaded exercise like the bench press.
D-Tier.additional_notes: The speaker used to do a lot of these in his early powerlifting days to build explosive chest power for the bench press.

F-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) because the arms never stretch out, staying tucked in the whole time, which prevents a big stretch in the pecs. It also fails to offer maximum tension because the triceps will take over. There is no evidence that these target the inner pecs; in fact, they would probably be worse for the inner pecs than a standard dumbbell press since the inner pec fibers are not getting as stretched.
F-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Inner pecs (no evidence, likely worse due to lack of stretch).
F-Tier.limitations: No big pec stretch. Triceps tend to take over. Ineffective for inner pecs.
F-Tier.additional_notes: The speaker is not a big fan of these.

F-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) as it's basically a hex press, offering even less stretch. Fails criterion 2 (feels good) as it feels even more awkward. Fails criterion 3 (simple progression) due to even less overload potential.
F-Tier.limitations: More awkward than a hex press. Even less overload potential.
F-Tier.additional_notes: Crowned as the 'worst of the worst' (F-tier Hell) for pec development.

F-Tier.execution_notes: Shrug your shoulders up, flare your elbows out, and lower the barbell down to your neck.
F-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 2 (feels good/safe) due to being potentially very dangerous; dropping the bar on your neck would be extremely hazardous. The potential hazard risk is not considered worth any potential marginal gains.
F-Tier.limitations: Potentially very dangerous (risk of dropping the bar on the neck).
F-Tier.alternative_options: A modified version using dumbbells is much safer and ranked A-tier.
F-Tier.scientific_insights: Dr. Mike (Mike Israetel) suggests there's no direct evidence or strong rationale to support claims that this exercise causes shoulder issues. Flaring the elbows can lead to a huge stretch in the pecs.
F-Tier.additional_notes: Has a cool history in lifting culture. The speaker believes that for some people, especially those with pre-existing shoulder issues, flaring the elbows might hurt.

F-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 2 (feels good) because doing one arm at a time makes it harder to keep your balance, which disperses tension away from the pecs. There is no advantage to performing this exercise one arm at a time, as each pec already works individually in a standard dumbbell press.
F-Tier.limitations: Harder to keep balance, which disperses tension away from the pecs.

F-Tier.execution_notes: Extend your arm across your body.
F-Tier.tier_reasons: Fails criterion 1 (big stretch with high tension) as the dumbbell offers literally zero tension when the pec is stretched. Fails criterion 2 (feels good) because it is basically a front raise, meaning the front delts will steal a lot of the tension from the pecs, even if you try to squeeze them at the top.
F-Tier.target_muscle_parts: Upper pecs (attempted, but front delts steal tension).
F-Tier.limitations: Zero tension when the pec is stretched. Front delts steal a lot of tension from the pecs.
F-Tier.alternative_options: Dumbbell flies lying down make a lot more sense biomechanically.

criterias.A big stretch with high tension: The exercise must provide significant tension while the muscle is in a deep, stretched position. Exercises lacking this are ranked low.

criterias.It needs to feel good: The exercise should not cause pain, have a smooth resistance profile, ideally provide a good pump, and facilitate a strong mind-muscle connection.

criterias.It needs to have a simple progression: The exercise must allow for consistent progressive overload, either by adding weight or increasing repetitions over time.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Pecs (General): Primary target for chest exercises. Involved in pressing movements, adduction (bringing arms across the body), and stretching. Activation is key for growth.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Inner Pecs: Specific fibers mentioned in the context of the hex press, which is noted for not effectively stretching these fibers.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Upper Pecs: Often a priority for growth, emphasized by incline movements (e.g., incline bench press, incline dumbbell press, incline Smith machine press). Can be targeted for full contraction with exercises like the cable press around or crossbody standing dumbbell fly.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Mid and Lower Pecs: Targeted by flat and decline pressing movements (e.g., flat bench press, decline bench press, decline dumbbell press). Decline angles are biomechanically suggested to emphasize these areas.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Front Delts: Targeted by compound chest exercises (presses, dips, push-ups). Can 'steal' tension from the pecs if not properly isolated or if form is compromised (e.g., crossbody standing dumbbell fly).

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Triceps: Involved in pressing movements. Can take over from the pecs if the pec stretch and tension are insufficient (e.g., hex press). Floor press is noted for 'smashing' the triceps and improving lockout strength.

muscle_part_anatomy_function.Lats: Involved in the dumbbell pullover movement, which is considered a better lat exercise than a pec exercise despite some pec activation.

main_knowledge_summary.form_details: For the bench press, bring the bar all the way down to your chest. In hex presses, arms stay tucked in, limiting pec stretch. Dumbbell presses (flat, incline, decline) allow dumbbells to move freely past the rib cage for a deeper pec stretch compared to barbells. When performing dips, the negative (lowering phase) can be slowed down. Deficit push-ups involve going below floor level for a deeper pec stretch, and pausing for 2-3 seconds at the bottom can increase challenge. The guillotine press (barbell) involves shrugging shoulders up, flaring elbows out, and lowering the barbell to the neck to maximize pec stretch. The dumbbell guillotine press uses the same basic movement with dumbbells for safety. For cable crossovers, bending forward and flying downward can improve stability. Dumbbell flies can be performed as 'length-biased partials' by cutting out the top half of the movement where tension is minimal. The cable press around involves pressing the cable across your midline to achieve full pec contraction. The crossbody standing dumbbell fly involves extending the arm across the body for upper pec contraction. The floor press has a limited range of motion as the movement stops when the elbows touch the floor.
main_knowledge_summary.training_keys: Prioritize exercises that provide a deep stretch with high tension on the pecs, feel good without causing pain, and allow for simple progressive overload. Avoid exercises like the hex press and plate press due to limited stretch and triceps takeover. The dumbbell pullover is better suited for lats. Barbell bench press offers high tension and overload but limits stretch and can cause shoulder issues if form is poor or ego lifting occurs. Incline bench press effectively targets upper, mid, and lower pecs. Decline bench press targets mid/lower pecs but has less range of motion and upper pec growth is often a higher priority. Dumbbell presses offer a deeper stretch than barbells and are generally safer for shoulders, but can be limited by dumbbell availability for advanced lifters. Machine chest presses are highly effective, providing deep stretch, high tension, stability for mind-muscle connection, easy overload, and safety for training to failure. Dips offer a massive pec stretch and high tension with various overload options, though some may experience shoulder discomfort. Bodyweight push-ups are good for beginners but require high reps for growth once strong; deficit push-ups are preferred for a deeper stretch. Plyometric push-ups are better for explosive power than hypertrophy. The guillotine press (dumbbell version is safer) can provide an excellent pec stretch. Avoid one-arm dumbbell presses due to balance issues and dispersed tension. Smith machine presses are effective and safer for pushing to failure. Cable crossovers and seated pec flies are excellent isolation movements for stretch and tension; seated variations offer more stability. Dumbbell flies are best performed as length-biased partials, focusing on the stretched position. The cable press around is valuable for achieving full pec contraction (short length biased work). Avoid crossbody standing dumbbell flies as they lack tension in the stretched position and engage front delts excessively. The floor press is good for triceps and lockout strength but suboptimal for pec hypertrophy due to limited range of motion.
main_knowledge_summary.research_insights: A recent study found that the incline bench press caused the same lower and mid pec growth as the flat bench press, in addition to better upper pec growth. Recent evidence suggests that the stretched position of a muscle is more important for muscle growth than the fully contracted position, which has led to a re-evaluation of exercises like the dumbbell fly. While there is research supporting explosive training, for bodybuilding purposes, an explosive tempo on weight-loaded exercises like the bench press is preferred over plyometric push-ups. Regarding the guillotine press, there is no direct evidence or strong rationale to support claims that it inherently causes shoulder issues; if it feels good and targets the pecs, it can be effective. Studies consistently show that the Smith machine is effective at building muscle across a variety of exercises.
main_knowledge_summary.optimization_notes: To optimize workouts, consistently apply progressive overload by adding weight or reps. For barbell bench press, avoid ego lifting to prevent shoulder issues. Advanced lifters using dumbbell presses may face limitations with dumbbell rack availability or awkward handling, requiring alternative strategies for overload. Dips can be progressed by reducing assistance weight, increasing bodyweight reps, slowing down the negative, or adding external load with a weight belt. If performing push-ups, consider deficit push-ups and incorporate pauses at the bottom for increased challenge. For dumbbell guillotine presses, start with light weight to build tolerance, especially when flaring elbows. Cable crossovers can be progressed by adding reps and focusing on technique. Dumbbell flies are optimized by performing them as 'length-biased partials' to maximize tension in the stretched range. Periodically include exercises like the cable press around to target the pecs in a fully contracted (short length biased) position. Machine chest presses are ideal for safely pushing to failure. Jeff Nippard's 'Pure Bodybuilding Program Phase 2' (and Phase 1) is mentioned as a resource for more exercises and intensity techniques for advanced progression.
